newsitem.title: USA: Plains feedlot cattle seen quiet Monday - trade.
newsitem.headline: Plains feedlot cattle seen quiet Monday - trade.

text.p: Plains feedlot cattle markets were expected to remain at a standstill Monday amid ideas that packers would not need to buy cattle until later in the week because of the record large number of head sold this week, feedlot sources said.
Most of this week's cattle were sold Tuesday at $68.00 per cwt, up $2.00 from the previous week
Asking levels for cattle next week could range from $69.00 to $70.00, with expected packer bids at $68.00.
Short packer supplies and a rebound in boxed beef prices contributed to this week's strong activity, the sources said.
Texas Panhandle/western Oklahoma feedlots this week sold a record large 155,400 head, soaring past the previous record of 136,800 set the week ended February 22 this year, USDA said.
Kansas feedlots also sold a record large number of cattle this week at 136,400 head, snapping the previous record of 115,059 set the week ended July 28, 1995, USDA said.
